#Text=CHAPTER VI .
#Text=MADAME LA VICOMTESSE
#Text=Hesitating on the step , a lady stood in the vine-covered doorway , a study in black and white in a frame of pink roses .
#Text=The sash at her waist , the lace mantilla that clung about her throat , the deftly coiled hair with its sheen of the night waters -- these in black .
#Text=The simple gown -- a tribute to the art of her countrywomen -- in white .
#Text=Mrs. Temple had gone forward to meet her , but I stood staring , marvelling , forgetful , in the path .
#Text=They were talking , they were coming towards me , and I heard Mrs. Temple pronounce my name and hers -- Madame de Montméry .
#Text=I bowed , she courtesied .
#Text=There was a baffling light in the lady ’s brown eyes when I dared to glance at them , and a smile playing around her mouth .
#Text=Was there no word in the two languages to find its way to my lips ?
#Text=Mrs. Temple laid her hand on my arm .
#Text=“ David is not what one might call a ladies ’ man , Madame , ” she said .
#Text=The lady laughed .
#Text=“ Is n’t he ? ” she said .
#Text=“ I am sure you will frighten him with your wit , ” answered Mrs. Temple , smiling .
#Text=“ He is worth sparing . ”
#Text=“ He is worth frightening , then , ” said the lady , in exquisite English , and she looked at me again .
#Text=“ You and David should like each other , ” said Mrs. Temple ;
#Text=“ you are both capable persons , friends of the friendless and towers of strength to the weak . ”
#Text=The lady ’s face became serious , but still there was the expression I could not make out .
#Text=In an instant she seemed to have scrutinized me with a precision from which there could be no appeal .
#Text=“ I seem to know Mr. Ritchie , ” she said , and added quickly :
#Text=“ Mrs. Clive has talked a great deal about you .
#Text=She has made you out a very wonderful person . ”
#Text=“ My dear , ” said Mrs. Temple , “ the wonderful people of this world are those who find time to comfort and help the unfortunate .
#Text=That is why you and David are wonderful .
#Text=No one knows better than I how easy it is to be selfish . ”
#Text=“ I have brought you an English novel , ” said Madame de Montoméry , turning abruptly to Mrs. Temple .
#Text=“ But you must not read it at night .
#Text=Lindy is not to let you have it until to-morrow . ”
#Text=“ There , ” said Mrs. Temple , gayly , to me , “ Madame is not happy unless she is controlling some one , and I am a rebellious subject . ”
#Text=“ You have not been taking care of yourself , ” said Madame .
#Text=She glanced at me , and bit her lips , as though guessing the emotion which my visit had caused .
#Text=“ Listen , ” she said , “ the vesper bells !
#Text=You must go into the house , and Mr. Ritchie and I must leave you . ”
#Text=She took Mrs. Temple by the arm and led her , unresisting , along the path .
#Text=I followed , a thousand thoughts and conjectures spinning in my brain .
#Text=They reached the bench under the little tree beside the door , and stood talking for a moment of the routine of Mrs. Temple ’s life .
#Text=Madame , it seemed , had prescribed a regimen , and meant to have it followed .
#Text=Suddenly I saw Mrs. Temple take the lady ’s arm , and sink down upon the bench .
#Text=Then we were both beside her , bending over her , she sitting upright and smiling at us .
#Text=“ It is nothing , ” she said ; “ I am so easily tired . ”
#Text=Her lips were ashen , and her breath came quickly .
#Text=Madame acted with that instant promptness which I expected of her .
#Text=“ You must carry her in , Mr. Ritchie , ” she said quietly .
#Text=“ No , it is only momentary , David , ” said Mrs. Temple .
#Text=I remember how pitifully frail and light she was as I picked her up and followed Madame through the doorway into the little bedroom .
#Text=I laid Mrs. Temple on the bed .
#Text=“ Send Lindy here , ” said Madame .
#Text=Lindy was in the front room with the negress whom Madame had brought with her .
#Text=They were not talking .
#Text=I supposed then this was because Lindy did not speak French .
#Text=I did not know that Madame de Montméry ’s maid was a mute .
#Text=Both of them went into the bedroom , and I was left alone .
#Text=The door and windows were closed , and a green myrtle-berry candle was burning on the table .
#Text=I looked about me with astonishment .
#Text=But for the low ceiling and the wide cypress puncheons of the floor the room might have been a budoir in a manor-house .

#Text=On the slender-legged , polished mahogany table lay books in tasteful bindings ; a diamond-paned bookcase stood in the corner ; a fauteuil and various other chairs which might have come from the hands of an Adam were ranged about .
#Text=Tall silver candlesticks graced each end of the little mantel-shelf , and between them were two Lowestoft vases having the Temple coat of arms .
#Text=It might have been half an hour that I waited , now pacing the floor , now throwing myself into the arm-chair by the fireplace .
#Text=Anxiety for Mrs. Temple , problems that lost themselves in a dozen conjectures , all idle -- these agitated me almost beyond my power of self-control .
#Text=Once I felt for the miniature , took it out , and put it back without looking at it .
#Text=At last I was startled to my feet by the opening of the door , and Madame de Montméry came in .
#Text=She closed the door softly behind her , with the deft quickness and decision of movement which a sixth sense had told me she possessed , crossed the room swiftly , and stood confronting me .
